problem: Think step by step and answer in short: Consider the integer\[N = 9 + 99 + 999 + 9999 + \cdots + \underbrace{99\ldots 99}_\text{321 digits}.\]Find the sum of the digits of $N$.
solution: Let's express the number in terms of $10^n$. We can obtain $(10-1)+(10^2-1)+(10^3-1)+\cdots+(10^{321}-1)$. By the commutative and associative property, we can group it into $(10+10^2+10^3+\cdots+10^{321})-321$. We know the former will yield $1111....10$, so we only have to figure out what the last few digits are. There are currently $321$ 1's. We know the last four digits are $1110$, and that the others will not be affected if we subtract $321$. If we do so, we get that $1110-321=789$. This method will remove three $1$'s, and add a $7$, $8$ and $9$. Therefore, the sum of the digits is $(321-3)+7+8+9=\boxed{342}$.

Let's first consider the sum $S = 9 + 99 + 999 + 9999 + \cdots + \underbrace{99\ldots 99}_\text{321 digits}.$

We can rewrite each term as a geometric series: \begin{align*}
9 &= 9 \\
99 &= 9 \cdot 11 \\
999 &= 9 \cdot 111 \\
9999 &= 9 \cdot 1111 \\
&\ \vdots \\
\underbrace{99\ldots 99}_\text{321 digits} &= 9 \cdot \underbrace{111\ldots 111}_\text{321 digits}.
\end{align*}In general, the $n^{\text{th}}$ term is $9 \cdot \underbrace{111\ldots 111}_\text{321 digits},$ where there are $n$ digits in the number.

We can factor out a $9$ from each term: \begin{align*}
9 &= 9 \\
99 &= 9 \cdot 11 \\
999 &= 9 \cdot 111 \\
9999 &= 9 \cdot 1111 \\
&\ \vdots \\
\underbrace{99\ldots 99}_\text{321 digits} &= 9 \cdot \underbrace{111\ldots 111}_\text{321 digits}.
\end{align*}In general, the $n^{\text{th}}$ term is $9 \cdot \underbrace{111\ldots 111}_\text{321 digits},$ where there are $n$ digits in the number.

Therefore, \begin{align*}
S &= 9 + 9 \cdot 11 + 9 \cdot 111 + 9 \cdot 1111 + \cdots + 9 \cdot \underbrace{111\ldots 111}_\text{321 digits} \\
&= 9(1 + 11 + 111 + 1111 + \cdots + \underbrace{111\ldots 111}_\text{321 digits}).
\end{align*}The sum $1 + 11 + 111 + 1111 + \cdots + \underbrace{111\ldots 111}_\text{321 digits}$ is a geometric series with first term $1$ and common ratio $10.$  Therefore, \[1 + 11 + 111 + 1111 + \cdots + \underbrace{111\ldots 111}_\text{321 digits} = \frac{10^{321} - 1}{9}.\]Hence, \[S = 9 \cdot \frac{10^{321} - 1}{9} = 10^{321} - 1.\]Finally, the sum of the digits of $N$ is $1 + 0 + 0 + \dots + 0 - 1 = \boxed{0}.$
